message_1: A Ferris wheel is 50 feet in diameter and has its center 25 feet above the ground at its lowest point. The wheel turns at a constant rate, taking 2 minutes to make one revolution. Write an equation for the height H of a person on the Ferris wheel as a function of time t, measured in seconds. Then graph the equation for one complete revolution.
message_2:
To write the equation for the height H of a person on the Ferris wheel as a function of time t, we can use the sine function, as the height varies sinusoidally with time. The Ferris wheel has a radius of 25 feet (half of the diameter), and its center is 25 feet above the ground. The wheel takes 2 minutes (120 seconds) to make one revolution.

The general equation for a sinusoidal function is:

H(t) = A * sin(B(t - C)) + D

where A is the amplitude (the radius of the wheel), B is the angular frequency, C is the phase shift, and D is the vertical shift (the height of the center of the wheel above the ground).

In this case, A = 25 feet (the radius), B = 2π / 120 (since the wheel takes 120 seconds to make one revolution), C = 0 (as there is no phase shift), and D = 25 feet (the height of the center of the wheel above the ground).

So, the equation for the height H of a person on the Ferris wheel as a function of time t is:

H(t) = 25 * sin((2π / 120) * t) + 25

To graph the equation for one complete revolution, we can plot H(t) for t ranging from 0 to 120 seconds. The graph will be a sinusoidal curve with a period of 120 seconds, an amplitude of 25 feet, and a vertical shift of 25 feet above the ground. The height will vary between 0 feet (at the lowest point) and 50 feet (at the highest point) as the wheel completes one revolution.
